WRITING.TEXT: I was stick thin growing up and I was bullied a couple years in school. The fat kids I can remember (there were like 2 because obese people were not as common) were not picked on. One was dick and the other was kinda just not noticed. This is a small sample size so take it with a grain of salt, but it defeats a notion as silly as saying that skinny people cannot be bullied worse than fat people. Anyone can be bullied.

Warrior is a class that is easy to be bad at. And there is never a shortage of monks and drg. If you really want to make a go of it I would recommend a healer or caster first and branch out. If you really want to tank, pld is a very simple class.

If it helps I will say that warlords of draenor is disappointing and it felt like they wanted to make it to where much top level content can be pugged. But wow used to be pretty challenging. Ulduar was probably the best example of how raiding should be done. Since then it had slowly been progressing to cinematic over innovation. No offense is taken. It's my opinion and it's based in my experience. Using a bit of exaggeration for humorous effect does not change it.

I was server 2nd twin kill. 4 other raid groups downed it on my server before the nerf. It was an intensely challenging fight thathad little to do with great gear I stopped playing after getting to turn 8 on coil. I went back to wow which had turned into a Facebook game (which was fun for a bit) and some pretty uninspired raid fights. Furnace and black hand were ok, preceded by don't stand in bad/ gear check fights. Mythic wasn't out yet, but I did some high maul mythic which were largely gear check versions of the hm. They were hard of course, but nothing mind blowing.

I never thought I'd see someone say that wow raids are more complicated than ffxiv. The most recent raids are designed so that just about anyone can succeed in wow. All content is very forgiving to mistakes. Whereas the first turn off of coil remained untoppled for months on my old server due to having fights that forgave no mistakes. Wow is more like "lol half the people died. That's OK. They were the carries".

I learned how to wind surf there. Guy ran a surf shop and agreed to give lessons for 30 dollars and a six pack of American beers from base. They are a good bartering item because the same items sold in Japan can give a bad aftertaste and headache due to how they preserve the beer in shipping. I'm sure he would have done it without the beer,but I do think it's why he cooked for us while we practiced.

From what I've read about battles, they aren't always two sides of well armed troops. Sometimes it is literally a farmer in his normal clothing with his sharpest tool.
